title: Public and Community Art
description: Public art is considered as an important cultural asset of metropolitan cities, closely related to city images and development. Community art serves as a tool for community development, based on the understanding that expression, mastery and communication through the arts powerfully encode cultural values, thus bringing deeper meanings of experience, participation and involvement, sense of belonging to the general public and the community. This course aims to advance students’ understanding of public and community arts by embedding them in the theoretical discussions and critiques of cities and public spaces and practical experiences. It also imparts the knowledge and skills about managing public arts and actualizing community art programs, and discusses the way to support their development responding to the needs.
outcome: In terms of knowledge acquisition, students are expected to understand how public and community arts emerged in the context of urban regeneration and community activist movements. Students are encouraged to critically analyze the meanings and social values of public art spaces. In terms of managerial concepts and skills, students will learn how public and community arts are supported by government policies, material resources, infrastructure and training. Students are expected to understand public art commission and reception, to master basic principles of utilizing public art as an urban design strategy, and to apply varying approaches to facilitating community art development, for example, advancing community art education, utilizing the cultural planning approach to assess community based cultural resources and the place-event approach to creating a sense of community attachment.
syllabus: Part I. Understanding Public and Community Art 1. General Introduction This section begins with displaying a range of public and community art cases and presents an introduction to the course. Three issues are covered in this introductory lecture. First, this section provides the conceptual discussions of public space, public art, and their art forms to enable students to understand what public art space and public art is. Second, this section explores the role of artists in public art space and community development. Third, a historical picture of public art is unfolded, which traces its origin, displays its developing process, and takes a glimpse into its enshrined social values.   2. Understanding Public Art Spaces  How should we understand public art spaces and the public nature of public art? This section embeds these issues into the understanding of a city; it then conveys the ideas that public spaces are socially produced and that city forms are imbued with ideologies. Public art stems from an urban setting and then grows through the urban regeneration movement, which comprises several issues, such as urban image, urban form and urban planning as well as their connections with public art space as a form of representational space. Furthermore, this section explores the public nature of public art by examining the process, by which artists derive value from individual creativity in the studios and immense it into the public space.  Tutorial: Discuss the alternative history of public art (Lacy, 1995, 25–28).  3. Public Art: The Monument The monument is an important theoretical perspective to conceptualize public art. This section explains what a “monument” is and investigates its role—whether statue, memorial, or public statue—in upholding a value-laden system of Western society. Issues under examination range from the connection between monument and national identity, the power and representation of public arts, the transformative understanding of public art as a monument, and the contradictions of public art.  Tutorial: Discuss the public nature of public art.  4. Critical Issues of Public Art Spaces Who comprise the “audience” of public arts? What does “intention” mean and what is the “effectiveness” of public art? This section further discusses the theories on critical issues related to public art. This section begins with the discussions of the relevant terms and proceeds to various critical thoughts that challenge the value of public art and question its public nature. Students are expected to be able to analyze public art spaces and public art critically. Tutorial: Develop critical thinking about public art spaces and public art.  5. Public Arts and Community Cultural Development: Theoretical Underpinnings of Community Art This section provides a synopsis of the histories and theoretical issues of community art. The origin of community art is traced to the discourse of William Morris’s call for social reintegration of artists and a revival of art in the 19th century. Theoretical issues include the “popular front” and class consciousness, civil rights and identity politics, as well as cultural democracy and exchange. In addition, this section discusses the definitions of community, the role of community art, and the core purposes of community development.  Tutorial: Discuss the question, “What makes art valuable?”   Part II. Public Art Management  6. Commission and Reception of Public Art Based on the public nature of art, this section analyzes the process of art making, which comprises the elements of audience, context, and meaning. The process includes the following: acquiring cultural approval, arriving in public sites and places, providing visiting experiences with the audience, and generating meanings. Cases of Seattle and New York are used for this study. With regard to art reception, it analyzes the issues of taste, the education of the audience, as well as the relationship of art to society and popular visual culture. In addition, this section also distinguishes performance culture from monumental public art. Tutorial: Distinguish public art from community art.  7. Public Art and Urban Design This section presents an urban design approach to commissioning and making public art. It outlines the principles for creating a city image, which consists of five elements, and discusses their connections to public art. Various forms of public art in association with the urban setting and the mechanism of public art utilization as an urban design strategy are also discussed. Students are guided toward understanding the role of public arts in urban design guidelines. Moreover, we also discussed a set of design principles on the relationship between public art and various urban forms and spatial components, aimed at integrating public art into the urban setting as context and reference is discussed. Tutorial: Conduct design software training.  Assignment: Find a sample of public art (i.e., sculpture) using design principles to assess its location, site, and designs as well as to evaluate its strengths and weaknesses. Write a paper based on the research and use the design software to illustrate the arguments.   8. Government Policies for Public and Community Art Development The relation between power and public and community art is a critical issue in public and community art management. This section discusses the governmental structure that funds and commissions public art, the infrastructure that underpins public art, and the governmental policies that support community art. The selection of commissions and projects is discussed, along with the process of seeking public and professional responses. International and the local Hong Kong contexts are examined to explore how government policies affect public and community art. In the local context, the role of the Leisure and Cultural Services Department in promoting public art in Hong Kong is adopted as a case study. Tutorial: Conduct an in-class test.   9. Public Art in Metropolitan Cities This section analyzes the role of public art in metropolitan cities, especially in the spheres of public transport, public open spaces, and public health system. A number of cases are presented, including forms of public art in the New York Subway system, London Underground and Mass Transit Railway, and the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Hong Kong. The issue of commissioning public arts is revisited in the public art in metropolitan context.  Tutorial: Discuss urban design and public art in Hong Kong.  Part III. Community Art Management 10. Developmental Needs of the Field How can community art development be supported? What do communities need? This section specifies the scope of cultural policies and the policy climate that community artists and community cultural development require. Moreover, this section discusses the material support that community cultural organizations and artists need, including funding supports and internal infrastructure and exchange. Tutorial: Discuss the cultural policies for public art in Hong Kong.  11. From Theory to Practice I: Process to Develop Community Arts From theory to practice, this section offers students a general orientation, which serves as a road map to the community-based art process. Five conceptual territories to advance community-based art as well as requisite techniques to fulfill tasks are introduced in this section, which include the following: 1) contacting people in the community; 2) conducting research on the culture of the community and the people’s perception of their community; 3) taking actions to make art projects; 4) gaining feedbacks from the community; and 5) incorporating these art forms into community art education programs to pass on skills and sustain the impact. The program also includes strategies for planning and organizing community outreach and engagement programs as well as ways to enhance public awareness. Tutorial: Discuss the process of applying theories in the creation of community art in order to practice and initiate the group project with the community.  12. From Theory to Practice II: Key Issues in Community Art Development Based on the holistic picture of the steps to develop community arts, this section focuses on certain key and challenging issues in the process, specifically those on research methods and art making. The section introduces qualitative and quantitative research methods for the project of community art development, and students are expected to learn how to identify survey areas, design survey questionnaires, run group discussions, and map cultural mind-sets and assets. Another key issue is how to make arts and work with artists. An artist will be invited to be the guest speaker to give the lesson. Tutorial: Develop a group project with the community.   13. Review and discussions Students will present their on-going group projects on community art development, and the professor then provides comments and feedbacks on their projects. Key points of this course will also be reviewed in this class.

title: Design Your Exhibition – Curatorial Planning and Practice
description: “Curator” once referred to an expert in keeping collections and making exhibitions, but has been expanded to encompass a hybrid role in innovation and knowledge creation. Today, curators are active agents in social and cultural transformation, taking part in dynamic projects presented by museums, commercial galleries, non-profit art spaces, biennials, art fairs, and many disruptive platforms beyond the field of art that didn’t previously exist. Curators produce knowledge, engage their audience, spark innovation, and constantly challenge the role of “curator” beyond the confines of the status quo across varied institutional settings. This course aims to provide students with hands-on experience in exhibition curation and engages students in a broad spectrum of real-world experiences and professional networking opportunities, aiming to prepare students for future curatorial projects/jobs. It covers topics such as idea conceptualization, proposal writing, pitching, budgeting, contracting, publication, exhibition design, installation and exhibition maintenance. By co-curating an exhibition in a non-profit art space in Hong Kong, students will take part in the various stages of exhibition making. With a focus on exhibition experience, audience engagement, and sociability, this course will train students in the role of being a curator and enable students to develop leadership skills and critically apply knowledge conducive to creative outcomes.

title: Entrepreneurship in the Creative Industries
description: The concept of “creative industry” was proposed by the Labor Party in the U.K. in 1997. It refers to the activities that are embedded in individuals’ creativities, talents and skills, which have the potential for employment opportunities and economic growth through the exploitation of intellectual properties. Creative industry has become a key area in contemporary cultural policies. This course introduces students to the basic knowledge of managing entrepreneurship, which is a key issue in the creative industries. It comprises three parts. The first part provides a general introduction. The second part discusses the nature of entrepreneurship in creative industries and demonstrates the entrepreneurial process, through which, creative ideas are generated, cultural diffusion is stimulated and innovation processes are carried out. It informs students of the key traits of the creative entrepreneurs and the business opportunities and models for entrepreneurship processes in the creative industries. In the third part, it explores the conducive policy conditions to support and encourage entrepreneurship in creative industries.

title: Curating and Organising Arts Festival
description: With a global growing interest in organizing grand scale arts and cultural activities to attract local and overseas audience, arts festivals have become popular urban cultural events for cultural development and for building the reputation of a city. Curating and managing cultural festival is subsequently an important area of studies in cultural management. Curating and organizing arts festival is a complex process that requires creative programming, skillful execution and careful financial control. This course not only studies the mode of operations of various types of cultural festivals, including festivals of performing arts, visual arts, film, literary arts and community festive celebration, but also introduces to students the basic skills and knowledge of curating and organizing arts festivals, with references to local and overseas examples.
outcome: - Understand the operation format, management process in organizing various types of cultural festivals; - Have the ability to curate and coordinate programmes within a specific arts/cultural festival; - Learn the supporting skills for successful implementation of arts/cultural festival, including publicity, marketing, public safety, security and finance control; - Equip students with the critical skills to review and evaluate the success and failure of a major cultural event.
syllabus: 1. Cultural Festival: an introduction  This session studies the history, social functions and basic modes of operation of cultural festivals, with examples from Hong Kong and fromvarious parts of the world.  2. Various types of festivals and their distinctive characters  This session introduces various types of arts festival, from festivals focusing on specific media, grand scale multi-disciplinary festivals, to community based religious/celebrative events, with emphasis on studying their own distinctive characteristics and special technical requirements.  3. Planning cultural festival 1:  This session focuses on programme planning and coordination, as well as resource management within the institutional and community context.  4. Planning festival 2:  This session deals with the planning of setting up an operation framework, allocation of manpower, design of the technical support and working out an operational schedule for a major arts festival.  5. Planning festival 3:  Funding is an essential part of organizing cultural festivals. This session studies the various ways to seek public and private fund, and ways to do financial planning and to exercise financial control over the running of projects.  6. Planning festival 4:  In addition to curating and implementing programmes, a successful festival also includes much supporting activities, ranging from marketing to educational events. This session focuses on the studies of these supplementary activities in order to get the best results for an arts event.  7. Presentation and discussion Students are asked to form groups to work on proposals for an arts festival. Students are to do their representations at class, and engage in discussion after the presentations.  8. Curation and programming This session studies the curation of festival programmes with references to local cultural strength and needs, the use of available resources, as well as a study of the global trends in arts festival.  9. Execution and crisis management This session studies the security measure for major cultural events, and preparations required for unexpected incidents and crisis.   10. Case studies Using the Hong Kong Arts Festival and Hong Kong Film Festival for case studies, this session studies the actual implementation of cultural festivals within the specific social, cultural and financial context of Hong Kong.  11. Evaluation and research The success of a festival depends heavily on responses from the audience, the press and the public, this session studies the application of marketing strategies and its consequent results, and ways to make meaningful evaluation for future development.  12. Critical issues relating to arts festival As arts and cultural festivals become increasingly prolific, its social and cultural impacts are not to be underestimated. This session takes on a critical review of the impacts, the pro and con of organizing arts festivals, as well as possible alternatives.  13. Review and discussion This session reviews the entire course and engages students in an over-all discussion.

title: Interpreting Chinese Antiquities
requirements: Not for students who have taken CUMT4101 Special Topics in Cultural Management (Heritage, Archaeology and Interpretation theme)
description: From the perspective of archaeology, this course is tailored to cross disciplinary boundaries between heritage and contemporary issues. The world of ancient China is a rich source of inspirations for museum work; tourism; films and documentary; literature; designs; and even commercial productions. Yet misinterpretations over Chinese history have led to problematic descriptions of heritage and archaeological sites. Indeed, there have not been many discussions of Chinese historical past independent of texts, and this course intends to fill up the lacuna. Taking ancient and medieval China as subjects, this course leads student to appreciate Chinese arts and archaeological finds from between the Neolithic and the 13th century. The course urges students to develop acute senses in reading and writing about heritage for contemporary needs.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students would be able to identify key historical sites and remains of pre-modern China; analyze the roles and management of heritage or its relevant institutions; think critically about historical exhibitions and other cultural events; develop acute senses for appreciating traditions and values; develop interests in culture and history; and get prepared for career related to management of heritage and arts industries.
syllabus: 1. Introduction: Why is material culture? What is heritage?  What is the difference between history and archaeology? Why should we pay attention to material objects? This session introduces the discipline of archaeology and describes its application in China. It defines what we speak of Chinese heritage from the perspective of material remains.   2. Neolithic China: The Rise of Numerous Jade-using Sources  As of 2014, more than 10 different Neolithic cultures have been identified in China. To what extent have we moved beyond the old understanding about Yangshao and Longshan cultures in central China? What do the new finds tell us about China during the Neolithic times (c.5000—c.2000 BC). And how do they fit into the unified picture of what we call ‘China’ today.   3. The Shang period: the Dawn of Civilization  There are some textual descriptions about the Shang dynasty. But its archaeological boundaries are subject to debates. This session introduces the key Shang sites in Henan, as well as their contemporary sites found in Sichuan, Hunan, and other Chinese provinces. It leads student to pay attention to the interpretation presented in most Chinese museum—all Bronze Age cultures were re-think the connections between the early Bronze Age and the present.   4. Western Zhou: The Early Development of Cultural Borrowings Western Zhou is understood as one of the most esteemed periods in antiquity. This session looks into the archaeological finds from the 10th to 8th century BC and discusses what bronzes tell us about the several important political decisions the Zhou courts made to consolidate sovereignty. One key policy that the Zhou founders implemented was adaptation to various cultural streams collected from the preceding Shang and other neighbouring groups. This was an unknown yet profoundly important aspect of the Zhou that prepared it for taking the lead of what we today call ‘Chinese’ civilization.   5. Eastern Zhou: The Age of Conformity The flourishing workshops of bronze-casting, lacquers, pottery, and textiles from the Eastern Zhou period provide a vast number of important archaeological finds. This session introduces some key sites, which include Sanmengxia and Leigudun. From them we will discuss the significance of material culture in forming shared heritage roots.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 45—63.  6. Han I: Burial Culture The Han dynasty is a promising period with many textual records and archaeological finds. This first session looks into the Han tomb structure and burial goods, which present some interesting patterns in the religious ideas and practices of the period.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 65—97.  7. Han II: the Silk Road Connections with the West were well-formed under the Han regime. This session looks at the finds from the Silk Road, which continued to be in use throughout the Han and its following centuries. This session reviews the finds from the Silk Road and discusses their significance for both the intellectual and public sphere in the present times.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 65—97.  8. Northern & Southern Dynasties: Buddhism in China Buddhism began to appear in China from the Han times, and became vastly important throughout the divided Northern and Southern dynasties. This session introduces the key caves of Buddhist sculpture and discusses the impacts of Buddhist ideas on later Chinese material creations. In particular, Buddhism helped develop a range of ornamental features unprecedentedly formed in the context of China; yet those features have become central in the presentation of Chinese heritage today.  Reading: Sullivan 2008, chapter 1, pp. 99—129  9. Tang Dynasty: The Cosmopolitan Cities  This session focuses on the settlement finds from the Tang period. Little is known about ancient Chinese cities or settlement sites, which were prone to destruction. title: Integrated Studies in Cultural Management
description: This course is continuation of CUMT1001, Introduction to Cultural Management, and looks at cultural management from the macro perspective. Successful culture managers work to maintain healthy balance between culture and its relevant fields of interests, which sometimes could turn harmful or beneficial to the growth and development of the corresponding cultural area. The first session discusses the mutual dependence between culture and various areas, which include laws, economy, community, national interests, and art practitioners. In practice, cultural managers usually have to conform to the values and ethnics of the corresponding countries. For that reason, the second session will look at the approach taken in a few remarkable examples, which Taiwan, China, Singapore, South Korea, U.K., and the U.S.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to explain different national and social concerns for preserving culture; to identify the legal and ethnic issues relevant to cultural productions; to identify marketing strategies in cultural promotion; to evaluate the measures for maximizing the input of art practitioners; and to describe the various successful cultural schemes implemented in overseas countries.
syllabus: Section I: Culture in Context   1. Culture & States The growth of cultural industries is strongly related to political environment and state policy. This lecture discusses the tension and mutual expectations between cultural workers and politicians. It will use the experience of the European Union and the US as examples.   2. Culture & Laws Over the last few decades, there were a number of remarkable disputes over international art transactions and copy rights. Given the growing size of the art market, knowledge about the previous cases is essential. This lecture takes the examples taken from the US for discussions.   3. Culture & UNESCO UNESCO is arguably a rising new power in forming a standard for evaluating cultural heritage of different nations. This lecture discusses the roles of UNESCO and its work in different cultural disciplines. National disputes over ownership of World Heritage sites will be bought up.   4. Culture & Community Nowadays many nations and countries perceive culture and heritage as means to empower developing communities. This lecture discusses the conservation of indigenous or minorities cultures, and its impacts on the majority population of the same community.   5. Culture & Marketing  Culture and business are often taken as two contrasting disciplines. One of the key issues in cultural management is to develop cultural audience with both education and economic concerns. Religious sectors are a growing body of cultural venues for tourism and heritage management. This lecture discusses the debated concerns about conducting marketing or business-driven strategies in cultural and religious areas.   Section II: Case Studies 6. Cultural Management in Taiwan Taiwan provides an excellent example to demonstrate the top-down organization of heritage sites. This lecture reviews a series of campaigns launched in Taiwan during the past twenty years, and discusses the reasons that may have contributed to engage the mass of Taiwan into different aspects of cultural industries.   7. Cultural Management in China China represents many upcoming opportunities in cultural management. This lecture reviews some recent moves: rapid establishment of museums, growing number of commercial galleries and auction houses, rise of new Confucian schools, introduction of university degrees in cultural management, etc. The lecture discusses the consuming force underneath the cultural growth in the Mainland.   8. Cultural Management in Singapore During the last two decades, the government of Singapore invested heavily on constructing cultural venues for both national and economic purposes. This lecture gives an overview of their establishment and invites students to reflect on the opportunities found in other areas of Asia.   9. Cultural Management in South Korea This lecture discusses the contemporary cultural policies undertaken in South Korea. During the last decade, South Korea featured an economic miracle in Asia by rejuvenating the distressed financial market with cultural developments, which included the film industry, heritage protection, publication, and cultural tourism.   10. Cultural Management in UK The United Kingdom was one of the earliest countries that invested heavily on promotion of cultural and arts events. This lecture gives a short history of the early developments made in the UK after the Second World War, and discusses the recent campaigns undertaken to break the boundaries between high arts and popular culture.   11. Cultural Management in USA The United States distinguishes herself from all other countries by boosting the absence of a ministry for arts and culture, yet artists and cultural workers receive due respects for their contributions. This lecture looks at the case of the US and examines her success in cultural management.   12. Group presentation This lecture is taken as a mock symposium for students to present their group projects and make comments on those by their peers. The presentation will be evaluated against the clarity and thoughts over the approved topics.   13. Conclusion: What is the best for Hong Kong?  This last session will summarize the topics covered throughout the course. Hong Kong is facing the challenge that many aspects of cultural developments in relation to urban planning, legislation, economy, national identity, and education are all pending. This lecture is an open discussion for students to brainstorm the possible approaches that Hong Kong could take in years to come.

title: Culture-led City Development
description: This course aims to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the culture-led city development phenomenon and equip them with the protocols for execution and practice. It comprises three blocks: Block 1 unfolds an overall picture of the phenomenon, introduces the related concepts, displays the disciplinary foundation of this topic, traces its history, and discusses the rationales and developing tendency. Block 2 studies the urban sociological and economic approaches employed in developing the theoretical foundation, highlighting a transition in capitalist production mode and urban governance upheld by public-private partnership modes. Criticisms are also presented to complete a dialectic mindset of this phenomenon. With a strong practical dimension, Block 3 teaches students various methods to make consultancy and policy recommendations for culture-led urban development projects. A variety of practices that constitute the culture-led strategy are discussed, such as how to plan for a creative city and cultural facilities, how to boost creative industries and develop cultural quarters and creative clusters, as well as how to revitalize historic quarters.

title: Archaeology and Modern Applications
description: Archaeology is an intriguing topic. In CUMT3009 Interpreting Chinese Antiquities, students are taught the essential contents and arguments in each Chinese archaeological period. At this advanced level, students are led to analyze the presentation of Chinese archaeological materials in different modern forms, which are namely, movies, novels, documentary films, museum displays, auction houses, and antique shops. Each class picks up a representative topic and a form of modern expression for discussions. Students of this course are required to have knowledge in Chinese archaeology, because the discussions are carried out in seminar forms, in which their inputs are required. The course gets students to apply the designs and innovations of ancient China to areas, which they may find interests that will eventually get in touch with the wide public.

title: Art and Propaganda
description: The course studies the history, theories and techniques of organizing cultural activities for social and political causes. It investigates the relationship between cultural expressions and the infrastructure of power, and the application of arts and culture for social, political actions, covering such major movements from the avant-garde of the 19th Century, the USSR and the Chinese propaganda movements, to the arts for civil right movements since 1960s. Case studies of similar movements in Hong Kong will also be included. The final part of the course will introduce to students the operational and managerial skill required for organizing such cultural activities.

title: Museum Studies
requirements: Not for students who have taken ANTH4720 or HIST5514
description: Museums have multiple roles in a society. They are academic institutes and public arenas for education. In the broad term, they represent national culture and communal heritage. This course leads student to understand museum exhibitions and management within social contexts. The lectures respond to the following issues: 1. What are the functions and achievements of museum activities? 2. In what ways can we understand and learn from an exhibition? What are the essential elements of museum catalogues and cultural writing? 3. How do museum workers balance both marketing and social needs? 4. In what ways can we participate in the operation of a museum? The course draws discussions from both the perspectives of museum workers and visitors. Some current issues concerning the roles of museums are also covered.
outcome: At the end of the course, students should be able to:  1. Identify the roles and management of museums; 2. Think critically about museum exhibitions and other cultural events; 3. Develop acute senses for art appreciation;  4. Develop interests in culture and history; and  5. Get prepared for career related to management of museums and cultural industries.
syllabus: 1 Introduction:What is a museum?  The introduction gives an overview of the museum structure and definition. This will introduce the various types of museums established around the world, defined according to the range of their collections. This will also compare the organization structure of a museum, in which the curatorial teams are working with a range of specialists relevant.   2 The history of museums  The ‘history’ of museum sounds alien to the context of museum studies. But museum workers are coming to beware that the museums are products of modernity that marked a distinctive times in which antiquities could be treated as shared, public properties. This lecture reviews the establishments of the Louvre and the British Museum in the 18th century; and discusses how ‘museums’ were contextualized first in Japan and later on in China.   3 Curatorship I: Exhibiting Authenticity and Interpretation As the last lecture recalls, ‘Museum as Ritual’ has become an established social understanding—museum is a place where esteemed objects are being exhibited and therefore recognized. The first problem that encounters all museum works is whether the objects they are showing, or the theme of the objects that they are presenting are ‘authentic’. In this lecture, we will look at examples of some early colonial museums and study the created themes that they presented.   4 Curatorship II: Organizing a thematic exhibition Putting up a thematic exhibition (alongside the permanent exhibition) is a common practice in most museums. This lecture will give instructions as to what elements a thematic show should include. Then students are organized into groups to do a role play session for three parties: museum workers, overseas collaborators, and the donors. From this exercise, students will learn about the difficulties in negotiations and planning.   5 Curatorship III: Museum publications and cultural writings The writings published for the museums share a common theme of identifying the artistic or historical values of the objects. In practice, however, there are various levels in addressing objects through literary practices. This lecture will look into some representative examples written for different targeted groups, which include children, pupils, and foreign visitors.   6 Museum and society I: Architecture and Design Renovation projects were undertaken in numerous renowned museums around the world, because it has become aware that museums have to catch up with young generations and with the rapidly developed cities, in which they are located. This lecture will look into the case of Doha Quarter, where the locals took a deliberate attempt to a museum compound. From such we will consider the significance of architecture and museum collection.   7 Museum and society II: Education and Application of Digital Technology  Smartphones and other technological devices have become useful sources for museum presentations and visits. This lecture reviews some applications both within the museum building and outside it. The lecture will also respond to the concerns that digital technologies may exhaust public interests in the museum collections. With these both sides of argument, this lecture leads students to consider both the usefulness and shortcomings of digital technologies.   8 Museum and society III: Patrons, Donors and Volunteers, the sources of Funding and Support Funding is always limited for cultural institutions. In this lecture, we will discuss the various potential fund sources for the museums. There is no standard way in the industry as to what the museum workers should do or write to apply for funding. But there are recognized sources about which they could get in touch: public visitors, membership programmes, volunteers, donars, and governmental resources. The key of the lecture is to develop an open mind to expand the coverage of funding from monetary values to public recognition.   9 Current issue I: Museum Branding and Marketing Museum branding has been identified as a major marketing strategy for cultural institution. In this lecture, we will look at the suggestions of some successful museum workers and study their marketing approaches by creating a brand for museums.   10 Current issue II: Soft Power and the Political Roles of Museums. As soon as Joseph Nye published his idea about soft power, which is based on the dissemination of cultural products or ideas, the discussion is always concerned with museum exhibitions. Museums could be taken as political statement of national treasures. In this lecture, we will discuss the ideas of Nye and look at how such concept has been interpreted in Asia.   11 Fieldtrip/site visit week  This week we will take some fresh air by visiting a local museum/site.   12 Current issue III: Museums and Contemporary Arts.  Should we include contemporary art in the context of museum? This is a difficult question that happens to most museums around the world. The well-used resolution is construction of a new venue dedicated to contemporary arts. The differences between the two disciplines—museums and contemporary arts—are related to the level of curatorship and public recognition. But the two themes seem to have blurred since the last decade.   13 Current issue IV: M+ and other museums in Hong Kong In this last session, we will return our discussion to Hong Kong and look at what options this city has in comparison from what we have seen in other parts of the world. The M+ is dedicated to contemporary arts, or experimental arts; but the local museums remain fairly traditional in terms of collection and their range of exhibitions. Can Hong Kong develop a cultural hub? If so, what roles do these institutes would play?

title: Advanced Museum Studies
description: This course picks up topics, which cannot be fully covered in CUMT4007 Museum Studies, but are essential for students pursuing careers in the area of museum and exhibition planning. This course is an advanced version, because it will touch on debated issues regarding museums. It focuses on installation, display, and site management. The purposes of the course may be summarized as follows: 1. What are the various display methods in museums? What are the concerns involved in selecting the ‘right’ ones? 2. How are museum workers (non-curatorial) trained? 3. What are the essential facilities a museum is expected to have? Why? 4. What is the role of museum in the contemporary arts, which is the area of debate regarding its significance and curatorship? The course develops students’ awareness towards global developments in world-class museums, so that they are equipped with skills and knowledge necessary for long-term competition in museums or other cultural institutions.

title: Research Project
description: Students are required to take either this course or “CUMT4103 Internship” to fulfill the capstone course requirements of the Programme. In this course, students are expected to be able to integrate the knowledge and skills that they learnt into a research project. This course has two specific objectives. First, it aims to allow the students to experience completing a coherent research project either by participating in faculty-directed projects as a research group member or conducting independent research under supervision. Second, it will help students develop the preliminary idea of applying theories to answering research questions. This can be done by adopting a constructivist approach with cultural theories to account for a certain phenomenon pertinent to cultural management, or by identifying resolutions based on positive social science theories for cultural management. A faculty member will be assigned based on the student’s area of interest for the research project.
outcome: The students are expected to develop a preliminary perception of academic or applied research, and understand the key steps of research, which include identifying and reviewing the key literature, developing a topic and focus for the research project, and mastering basic methods for data collection, analysis, and application of theories. The process of completing a coherent research will enable students to enrich research skills, such as applying theories, identifying problems, and conducting data collection and analysis.
syllabus: The students will work closely with their supervisor, starting from the second semester of year 3. In the middle of the semester, the students will submit their proposals, which should include literature review, research topic/focus, research question/problem identification, and research design. The key literature of the specialized area should also be identified. The students will be required to prepare and to have an annotated bibliography approved by the supervisor. The literature review should include the mainstream knowledge for doing cultural management in a specialized area, the nature of the management process, and the political, economic, and organizational contexts, in which cultural management is done.  A research topic or focus will be developed based on the observation and interest of the students. The students should seek the advice of the supervisor in deciding the topic or focus, and in doing the succeeding research design. Materials covered under research design include problem identification, hypothesis generation, and major issue and concept. The supervisor will also advise students about the basic qualitative and quantitative research methods, such as statistical methods, interview, and participatory observation, appropriate to developing a conceptual framework. Alternatively, students may identify a social phenomenon pertinent to cultural management or a cultural phenomenon represented by artistic or intellectual works. Students will be encouraged to apply computer-programming techniques covered in related courses.  Students who participate in faculty directed research projects may have the opportunity to avail of partial or full funding for their research and field trips depending on the funding situation. Their work should contribute to the research projects of their supervisors. The students will be advised on how to fulfill the required research tasks and improve their academic writing techniques.  This research project will lead to the completion of a thesis or its equivalent, and further studies at the graduate level. Part of the final product will be a presentation on the research project open to the university. The date for presentation is subject to future arrangements.

title: Internship
description: Students are required to take either this course or “CUMT4102 Research Project” to fulfill the capstone course requirements of the Programme. This course has two specific objectives. First, it aims to assist the students’ understanding of the way that cultural organizations or institutions operate. Students will acquire the chance to observe the organization’s administrative structure with regard to the external policy environment, its strategies for development, partnership with other organizations, the management styles, approaches and methods and decision-making procedures. Second, it will allow students to gain the experiences through the transition from classroom learning to in-practice learning. Students are expected to reflect their learned knowledge with the live cases during the intern and apply professional norms to assess the functionalities and performances of the organization. Recommendations for improvements based on identified challenges and problems that the organization faces will be included into their final reports. A faculty member will be assigned based on the student’s area of interest for the internship.
outcome: The internship will prepare students with the direction of career development in cultural management related areas. Upon completion of this internship course, students will have acquired first-person work experiences in his or her interested aspects of cultural management. Students will also deepen the understanding of the classroom knowledge with self-reflection and develop hand-on skills by applying the knowledge to administrative practices.
syllabus: The internship is typically taken by BA degree students within a cultural agency or organization during the summer vacation period at the end of the third year. The duration of the internship is six to eight weeks and it is normally full-time work (240-320 hours), subject to the agreement with the corresponding party. There might be exceptional cases in which students are engaged in part-time internship programmes held during the academic year because of the scheduling of specific arts projects. During the internship, students are expected to maximize the opportunities to access the staff, board meetings, internal and cross-organizational communications, in order to develop the understanding of the operation of the organization through participatory observation. To enhance on-job professional experience, the students are expected to complete professional management tasks independently or as a member of the agency’s management team with maximized exposure to the entire management process. The students’ internship will be largely in the charge of a field supervisor in the agency. It is important to have adequate on-job supervision that clarifies the policies and job requirements. The student’s supervisor in the Programme will provide advices regarding how to prepare the students for the working environment, carry out on-site observations, and write the final report. The Programme endorses the students’ full-time/part-time internships to fulfill the requirement for the BA degree.   List of available organizations will be announced and interviews arranged normally three to four months prior to actual participation of internship, Students are required to identify three options of organizations, with advices from the internship panel. Arrangement will be made for interviews and the final decisions are to be made by the organizations.  Option is opened for students to suggest organizations that are not of the list provided by the Programme. The suggested organizations must meet the following criteria: 1) Confirmed interest in offering internship; 2) Established organization with proper operational office, full time staff and creditable reputation; 3) Could provide a safe and proper learning/working environment; 4) No possible conflict of interest or personal linkage that might affect the final assessment. Based on the above criteria, the internship panel would make decision regarding the inclusion of the organizations into the internship programme.   Students are urged to timely hand in copies of documentary outputs, if any, of the intern employment, or reports prepared as a part of their internship experience. Arrangement for discussions with their Programme supervisors regarding the internship experience and critiques is encouraged. Students’ performance during the intern should be assessed by their field supervisors. A reviewing letter from the supervisor should be submitted, which contributes to the students’ final grades. In addition to the field supervisors’ assessment, students’ final report and a presentation open to the university are required and will be graded.  In case the student prefers academic pursuit or has tried and failed to obtain an internship, the student may consider conducting an individual research project or participating in faculty-directed research projects as specified in “CUMT4102 Research Project.”
